Authors: Paulo H Labiak, Kenneth G. Karol
Title:
Plastomes sequences of an ancient fern lineage reveal
remarkable changes in gene content and architecture
Abstract:
 PREMISE OF THE STUDY: Comparative analyses of plastid
genomes have suggested that gene order and content are relatively stable
across the main groups of land plants, with significant changes rarely
reported. We examine plastome organization and RNA editing in ferns, an
ancient lineage of vascular plants, and report changes that add valuable
information on plastome evolution in land plants.  METHODS: Using
next-generation sequencing methods we fully sequenced plastomes from
three Schizaeaceae species, and compared their plastomes with other
groups of land plants to study changes in gene composition, plastome
architecture, and putative RNA editing sites. We also performed Maximum
Likelihood and Bayesian Inference phylogenetic analyzes using 46
plastid-encoded genes, including 26 ferns, two gymnosperms and five
angiosperms.  KEY RESULTS: Within the Schizaeaceae, plastomes were
similar to each other in gene content and architecture. Striking changes
compared with other ferns include the complete loss of ndh genes and
reduction of the small single copy. Putative RNA editing was identified
in all three plastomes, a characteristic that is shared with other fern
groups. The monophyly of Schizaeales and Schizaeaceae was
confirmed.
